awd_titl_txt: Cross-laminated Timber Panels from Low-value Northeastern Woods
awd_abstract_narration:
Cross laminated timber is a processed building material that is opening up new opportunities for wood in the construction industry. Made from lumber glued together in crosswise layers, the material is used in floor, roof, and wall assemblies in building construction.  The product is an environmentally friendly alternative to steel and concrete. Its composite nature is forgiving of defects to an extent, making it a promising construction material of varied quality, small-diameter, and environmentally threatened wood species in Northeastern forests of the United States. This project pursues research that will develop basic understanding of the processing and properties of cross laminated timber panels made from low-value wood. Use of wood from forest provides significant environmental benefits because wood sequesters carbon, and creates less air and water pollution in production when compared to other building materials, in addition to being renewable and sustainable.

The goal of this research is to develop timber panels with natural defects and delineate its properties on a scientific basis. The project will pursue the following:  1) Develop probabilistic models for mechanical properties of cross laminated timber that has defects of knot, shake, and slope of grain; 2) Develop stochastic finite element model for the mechanical response of cross laminated timber panels; and 3) full-scale laboratory panel testing to validate finite element model. The project outreach will be pursued by inclusion of stakeholders of foresters, architects, and engineers in pursuing experimental tests. The students working on this research project will gain valuable experience in numerical and experimental methods.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Cross-laminated timber (CLT) is a revolutionary building technology that is opening up new opportunities for wood in the construction industry.  Comprised of orthogonal layers of sawn lumber, the material is used in floor, roof, and wall assemblies in large-scale construction as an alternative to steel and concrete.  

This work investigated the structural feasibility of using Massachusetts grown Eastern Hemlock and Eastern White Pine in conjunction with high strength machine stress rated (MSR) lumbers in hybrid CLT panels. Specifically, proof-of-concept research was conducted to demonstrate processing/fabrication procedures, experimental characterization of material properties, and implementation of constitutive models for use in advanced engineering analysis and design.  The research was separated into three phases:

1) an experimental phase which characterizes and probabilistically models defect content and material parameters of the lumber. All lumber used in making the CLT panels was visually graded and non-destructively tested to measure spatial MOE. The size and location of knots were physically recorded and imaging surfacing was conducted. A probabilistic model was developed and implemented to randomly generate knot type, diameter, orientation and frequency and was validated against recorded data of the real samples (see Figure 1).

2) a numerical modeling phase which focused on development of computational models to simulate the stochastic behavior of CLT.  Finite Element Models were created to simulate the effects of interior and edge knots on compressive stress and stiffness (see Figure 2). Stress concentrations were found to be largest at edge knots, particularly when knots are modeled as holes. 

3) another experimental phase which evaluated full scale panel behavior. A total of ten hybrid panels (five Hemlock and five Pine) were fabricated for evaluation.  For each species, the top layer comprised of stress grade No.1 or better, the mid-layer of No.2 & No.3, and the bottom layer was 2100f - 1.8E MSR lamstock. Four panels of each species were used for long-span bending tests and the fifth was cut into 4 specimens for short-span shear tests.

Both Eastern Hemlock and Eastern White Pine hybrid panels surpassed bending and shear requirements of standard PRG320 CLT Grades. The long-span bending tests resulted in characteristic bending capacities of 74x106 N.mm/m and 66x106 N.mm/m, and bending stiffness of  864x109 N.mm2/m and 899x109 N.mm2/m for Eastern Hemlock and Eastern White Pine hybrid CLT panels, respectively. Shear properties of the panels were measured by conducting short-span bending tests per species which resulted in characteristic shear capacity and stiffness of 120 kN/m and 12.1x106 N/m for Eastern Hemlock, and 118 kN/m and 15.1x106 N/m for Eastern White Pine hybrid CLT panels. (See Figure 3).

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts that result from this work are numerous. Value-added products are seen as a means of both defraying the costs of thinning and maintaining the economic viability of forestland which makes up the majority of the Northeastern region.  Creating new markets for these low-valued local trees will help create green jobs in rural communities and spur economic development for the local forest industry, setting an example for other regions. It will also help preserve the future health and sustainability of our forests so that they are neither left unmanaged nor removed for development. Furthermore, this work has significant environmental benefits as it promotes the development and use of wood: the only renewable major building material that has been shown to have substantially less global warming potential, air and water pollution, and embodied energy than steel or concrete.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this work is the contribution of mechanical data on CLT panels made from Eastern Hemlock and Eastern White Pine as well as lumber knot characterization databases and correlated material property databases. We developed layered-laminate modeling techniques and corresponding constitutive models specific to CLT panels.  

 

 


Last Modified: 12/15/2019
Modified by: Peggi L Clouston

Cross-laminated timber (CLT) is a revolutionary building technology that is opening up new opportunities for wood in the construction industry. We developed layered-laminate modeling techniques and corresponding constitutive models specific to CLT panels.
